items.title: Can I use nbdime to get differences between notebooks programatically with a Python script?
items.body:
Hello,

Thanks for this tool, it's really useful.

I'm opening this issue because after looking for a while about this, I haven't really found anything related.

My current use case implies having to get the diff output between two notebooks programatically, using a Python script, instead of using the `nbdiff` shell tool. Using a subprocess that runs the command it's probably not an option.

In a Python console, I've tried importing the `nbdime` package, and tried both `nbdime.diff` passing the two json jupyter notebooks, but all I get is a dictionary in what I assume is then used internally for other operations. I've also been having a look to the `nbdime.prettyprint` module, with no luck.

Is this possible? I don't really care if it implies performing several operations.

Thanks in advance

items.title: Git Integration: git diff not defaulting to nbdime diff
items.body:
I can't seem to quite achieve the intended behavior per the [docs](https://nbdime.readthedocs.io/en/stable/vcs.html) re: Git integration. I have installed `nbdime` into my virtual env, stepped into the virtual env, and registered the drivers via `git-nbdiffdriver config --enable`.

While the tool is great when called upon in the command line (e.g., `nbdime-web diff`, `nbdime diff`), whenever I'm working and run a `git diff`, I don't get the nice diff format generated by `nbdime`.

My `.gitattributes` looks like the following in my repo:

```git
# This is for a different package (nbstripout)
*.ipynb filter=nbstripout

*.ipynb diff=jupyternotebook
*.ipynb merge=jupyternotebook

```

And my `.git/config` file looks like this:

```git
[core]
	repositoryformatversion = 0
	filemode = true
	bare = false
	logallrefupdates = true
	ignorecase = true
	precomposeunicode = true
[remote "origin"]
         # Omitted :) 
[branch "master"]
	remote = origin
	merge = refs/heads/master
[filter "nbstripout"]
	# Omitted :)
	smudge = cat
[diff "jupyternotebook"]
	command = git-nbdiffdriver diff
[merge "jupyternotebook"]
	driver = git-nbmergedriver merge %O %A %B %L %P
	name = jupyter notebook merge driver
[difftool "nbdime"]
	cmd = git-nbdifftool diff \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\" \"$BASE\"
[difftool]
	prompt = false
[mergetool "nbdime"]
	cmd = git-nbmergetool merge \"$BASE\" \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\" \"$MERGED\"
[mergetool]
	prompt = false
```

Seems that everything is in place. What am I missing? 🤔  Anywho, very appreciative of this utility!

items.title: Conflicting merge decision with both addrange and removerange blows up UI
items.body:
The nbmerge-web UI TypeScript assumes `removerange` is only ever coupled with `patch`, but I've encountered case there's a conflicting `local_then_remote` merge decision with `addrange` and `removerange` for `local` and `remote` respectively:

```
Uncaught (in promise) Error: Invalid merge decision, cannot have null base for deleted cell: [object Object]
    at t.CellMergeModel.applyCellLevelDecision (cell.ts:495)
    at t.CellMergeModel.processDecisions (cell.ts:368)
    at new t.CellMergeModel (cell.ts:134)
    at t.NotebookMergeModel.buildCellList (notebook.ts:237)
    at new t.NotebookMergeModel (notebook.ts:92)
    at merge.ts:75
    at _ (merge.ts:165)
```

There are two possible approaches to solving this:

1. Fix the web UI so it can handle this pairing.
2. Change the merge algorithm so it doesn't output merge decisions that pair `addrange` and `removerange`.

I initially attempted the first approach, but the assumption that `removerange` is only ever coupled with `patch` seems to go pretty deep, so I ended up doing the second approach instead.

items.title: NBDime REST API changes for git diffs
items.body:
Hi @vidartf and others,

I'm touching base on the work proposed to add visual diff in the Git extension in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab-git/issues/331

### Current world

The nbdime REST API  (`/nbdime/api/diff`) provides diff for at a file level

1. Two versions of a notebook file (i.e. specifying base and remote)
2. passing in base as `git:$FILE_NAME` and that computes the diff between version of the file in the Git *working directory* and *HEAD*


### Proposed changes

To support diffs across the Git workflow, the proposal was to enhance this API to allow diff'ing between multiple points such as between two arbitrary git refs(equivalant of `git diff $OLD_COMMIT $NEW_COMMIT` or Diffing the changes in the staging area (equivalent of `git diff --staged`)

There are two ways to go about this

1. Add fields to the existing diff API that allow this functionality
    * Pros: Few changes needed to nbdime
    * Cons: Since the current nbdime API works on a single file, the Git extension has to find all the files that changed between the two git refs and invoke the nbdime API multiple times

2. Add a specific APIs for Git diffs that provide diff for all files based on the Git context passed
    * Pros: 1 API call from the client perspective and no need to pass the file name
    * Cons: Relatively more changes needed to nbdime and  a bit specific to Git

Both will work but I wanted to gather any feedback before embarking on this work.

items.title: Diff-web output to file
items.body:
Apologies if I've missed if this is already an option.

I'd like to be able to output nbdime diff-web to a file, from the command line without a UI.

Specifically, I'm hoping to script out the generation of nbdime diff outputs for each commit in a range -- ie, for a pull request touching notebooks, to show the changes commit-by-commit.

Context:

Changing code is hard, reading code is harder, reading diffs is pretty hard, and reading .ipynb diffs is even harder :) That's why 'nbdime diff' is compelling. Another strategy that helps is to break up even slightly complicated changes in to a series of smaller commits, each of which (as much as possible) do just one atomic thing. Unfortunately it's a little tricky to take advantage of both nbdime diff and a large number of small commits together. That's what's led me to want to script around (headlessly) collecting processed notebook diffs for a sequence of commits.

items.title: dockerfile for building this from source
items.body:
Hi there,

Just figured I'd let you know in our fork we have a working Dockerfile for building this from source: https://github.com/dotmesh-io/nbdime/blob/master/Dockerfile 

needed this rather than doing `pip install nbdime` because we had some other changes we made in order to integrate it into the product we're building. We also ripped out some features (uploading a file object over the api, accessing files from local storage, limiting the scope of urls) in order to make it secure when running in a container on a web server.

The Dockerfile looks a bit complicated because we found just doing `pip install .` inside a container meant the `lerna bootstrap --hoist` command failed for unknown reasons.

Let me know if there's anything you want us to submit as a PR upstream (I just submitted a bug I found while doing this using my own fork), and thank you for making this project so that we didn't have to build notebook diffing ourselves.

items.title: Add support for a client request prefix parameter to nbdiff-web
items.body:
I'm trying to run nbdiff on AWS Sagemaker (using Jupyter Lab) but running into this blocking problem.

Inside the Sagemaker environment, running an app on a port is automatically made available through a prefix appended to the the request string. So an nbdiff instance running on `http://127.0.0.1:44021/difftool` would be made externally available at  `http://PUBLIC_HOST/proxy/44021/difftool`. This breaks the app however as it assumes the JavaScript asset `nbdime.js` is located at `/static/nbdime.js` when it's actually found at `/proxy/44021/static/nbdime.js`. The same problem occurs within nbdime.js, where all the api requests assume the api endpoints are found at `/api/`.

`nbdiff-web` has the `base-url` parameter, however this changes the prefix for both URL routes and also client requests, so this doesn't work. It seems like a separate request prefix param is required for when a web host has implicitly set a requests prefix.

items.title: Question: nbdime config-git and virtualenvs
items.body:
I only recently started using nbdime, so I hope I did not overlook something obvious. My questions concerns the use of `nbdime` inside virtualenvs.

I install all my packages, including jupyter & nbdime, inside a virtualenv. However, after using `config-git`, my git config will contain references to the nbdime tools inside PATH. E.g., 

```
[diff "jupyternotebook"]
	command = git-nbdiffdriver diff
```

This way, `git diff` will fail, when run outside the current virtualenv. I worked around this issue by manually including the full path to the tools. E.g., 

```
[diff "jupyternotebook"]
	command = /full_path_to_my_venv/bin/git-nbdiffdriver diff
```

My question now is: What is the preferred way to install nbdime in a virtualenv and use it with git? Would you recommend to include the full path?

items.body:
If I configured git to use nbdime:

    nbdime config-git --enable --global

Is there a way to temporarily use git directly, overriding this configuration or having nbdime pass through without doing its magic?

items.title: how to use nbdime to only commit code cell changes?
items.body:
I have nbdime configured to be used as a driver for 'git diff' and 'git merge':

    nbdime config-git --enable --global

and I have nbdime configured to ignore all but code cells: (`~/.jupyter/nbdime_config.json`):

```
{

  "Extension": {
    "source": true,
    "details": false, 
    "outputs": false,
    "metadata": false
  },

  "NbDiff": {
    "source": true,
    "details": false, 
    "outputs": false,
    "metadata": false
  },

  "NbDiffDriver": {
    "source": true,
    "details": false, 
    "outputs": false,
    "metadata": false
  },

  "NbMergeDriver": {
    "source": true,
    "details": false, 
    "outputs": false,
    "metadata": false
  },

  "dummy": {}


}

```
so now when I do 'git diff' I get:

```
## modified /cells/4/source:
@@ -1,3 +1,4 @@
+#test
 from pathlib import Path
```

which is perfect.

Now, the notebook under git control has everything committed (outputs, metadata, etc.). **I want git to ignore any changes in outputs, metadata and details and commit only changes in code cells, exactly as it's shown in 'git diff' (via nbdime configured to only diff code cells).**

How can I commit just the code changes?

I tested what I have now and I get all changes committed, not just code cells.

One way nbdime could do that is to:

- extract code cells diff
- replace modified notebook with the clean checked out version before any changes
- apply the diff
- commit

but I don't know how to make nbdime to do that (or perhaps it does it already).

and I realize that the diff might not apply, if there are cells that were added and removed, so perhaps this is not an option at all.

**edit**: So we ended up using nbstripout to remove all but what's needed to be stored under git. Next is to figure out how to do automated merging a stripped out notebook under git with the local unstripped out notebook. I was thinking that perhaps nbmerge could mirror nbstripout's logic and be able to automatically merge the two, knowing which cells are important and need to be merged and which cells can be ignored.

Thank you.

items.title: nbdime+ jupyter: select/copy-n-paste doesn't work for code cells
items.body:
I've stumbled upon a very strange problem. When diff is shown via jupyter - the code cells in the diff can't be selected/copied to be pasted somewhere else. This defeats the purpose :(

I saved the html and reduced the problematic html to:

`<div class="CodeMirror-scroll" tabindex="-1" draggable="true">`

if draggable is set to false it works (the text is selectable/copyable), with true it doesn't.

everything else on the page can be selected/copied just fine.

I had to save the diff as html and to run:

`perl -pi -e 's|draggable="true"|draggable="false"|' diff.html`

and then I was able to extract the code diff I was after.

this is with nbdime-1.0.1 - same behavior with both firefox and chrome on ubuntu.

Thank you.

items.title: dev version build / install issues
items.body:
Trying to use your unreleased version, I tried to build a dev env as explained here using python 3.6.5:
https://nbdime.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installing.html#installing-latest-development-version

I think I figured out all the issues, and posting the below for the benefit of other users who might have similar issues, and perhaps some of these could be added to the docs if you feel it fits.

1) I didn't have venv and had to install it (it won't install it via pip):

`apt-get install python3-venv`

2) Initially, I couldn't get past:

```
python3.6 -m venv myenv
Error: Command '['/home/stas/python-dev/myenv/bin/python3.6', '-Im', 'ensurepip', '--upgrade', '--default-pip']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
```

Googling I found that ubuntu's python package doesn't include `ensurepip`, so I had to manually add it:

```
wget https://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.6.5/Python-3.6.5.tgz
tar -xvzf Python-3.6.5.tgz
cp -r ./Python-3.6.5/Lib/ensurepip /usr/lib/python3.6/
```

Then I was able to complete the build. 

3) Another note: The build won't work as root, only as user.

4) Finally, how do I now invoke jupyter notebook to use this custom environment? I'm new to virtualenv - reading the docs on it, it seems that the deployment should be:

```
cd ~/python-dev
python3.6 -m venv myenv
source myenv/bin/activate
jupyter notebook
```

and perhaps a link to: https://docs.python.org/3/library/venv.html

p.s. perhaps the docs can be modified to include the creation of a directory where the new environment is built, so that it can be shown in the deployment steps as I have shown above. e.g.:

```
mkdir ~/python-dev
cd ~/python-dev
python3 -m venv myenv          # For Python 2: python2 -m virtualenv myenv
source myenv/bin/activate
pip install nodeenv
nodeenv -p
```

Thank you.

items.title: notebook nbdime diff: Hide unchanged cells
items.body:
I'm using nbdime-1.0.1. 

`http://localhost:8888/nbdime/git-difftool?base=fastai%2Fcourses%2Fdl1%2Flesson1.ipynb`

Hitting: Hide unchanged cells

still shows all the code cells, changed and unchanged. The only difference is the the right column where the cell is unchanged is empty. This seems to be a bug, as it's not hiding the unchanged cells.

![nbdime-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10676103/41248830-0477b628-6d67-11e8-8714-6c4c4e7ec07e.png)

Perhaps the issue is that In[\d\d] is different in the original and the modified notebook. Yet if I don't hit 'Hide Unchanged cells' it doesn't display them as changed - and show to the full screen width.

Yet, it does report/hide some unchanged cells properly:

![nbdime-3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10676103/41249365-cae78940-6d68-11e8-8954-91d78f5477d2.png)

So, something is incomplete.

both snapshots are from the same diff.

Thank you!

items.title: Feature request: 2-way interactive merge
items.body:
Maybe this is too unusual a use case but maybe not.

I have some Jupyter notebooks that are used interactively, but which I also turn into Jekyll blog posts (as a separate copy of the notebook with some changes). There are some differences between the two; e.g. the blog posts don't have a title line (as that goes in a separate .meta file), the first paragraph are two are typically different, the blog posts have a HTML fragment to mark the end of the "teaser" text, and the last paragraph may be different.

After initially making these changes, I may later make changes to the notebook, and I want to have those changes carry over into the blog post. A normal 3-way merge doesn't apply here; the two notebooks don't have a common parent anymore. What I really want is the ability to do a 2-way diff in the browser, but then be able to interactively apply a selected set of the changes from one notebook to the other.

items.title: git-config could use full path to helpers, if nbdime config-git called with full path
items.body:
Hi,

I'm installing nbdime on a managed HPC system (which I am managing).  It is installed in a conda environment for juyterhub, and we try to avoid messing with system-wide installations.  When I enable nbdime for a git repository (`nbdime config-git --enable`), it puts the helpers in `.git/config` without an absolute path.  This means this conda environment has to be loaded to use the helpers.  I'd like to have the helpers be available regardless of what environment is loaded.  (we use Lmod also to manage `PATH`s, so there are lots of options here.

It would be nice if:
* I call nbdime with its's full path: `/share/apps/PATH/TO/nbdime config-git --enable`
* It puts the full path `/share/apps/PATH/TO/git-nbdiffdriver` in `.git/config`, instead of the name only `git-nbdiffdriver`

I see that non-absolute paths are hardcoded here, for example: https://github.com/jupyter/nbdime/blob/master/nbdime/vcs/git/diffdriver.py#L40.  Fix could be (possibly) `os.path.join(os.path.dirname(sys.argv[0]), 'helper')`.

This would allow me to give a single command (nbdime config-git with full path) to users to install nbdime for a git repository, without having to make any other system-wide configuration.

This is better than requiring a specific environment to be loaded, asking people to fix the paths, or installing or symlinking to the global PATHs.  Of course, absolute paths might change, but from what I understand running the enable script again should fix it.  I could make an initial PR if you think this is useful.

items.title: Add option to ignore empty cells
items.body:
Would be nice with an option to ignore empty cells, both added and deleted.

I tend to create a bunch of empty cells at the bottom of my notebooks, in order to be able to scroll the bottom-most cell with content higher up the page, and sometimes I forget to delete the extra cells.

items.title: Diffs very slow
items.body: When I use nbdiff it takes several minutes for the diff to appear. This happens when I do it from the terminal, use the web diff command, or use the jupyter extension.

items.title: Add option to ignore execution count
items.body:
The execution count can lead to a lot of noise in the diff. I know it's dangerous to ignore them, but since my notebooks is always designed to be executed in a "linear fashion", I'd really like to option.

I tried to achieve it by putting the following in my `~/.gitconfig`, but to no avail:
```
[difftool "nbdime"]
        cmd = git-nbdifftool diff --ignore-outputs --ignore-metadata --ignore-details \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\"

[diff "jupyternotebook"]
        command = git-nbdiffdriver diff --ignore-outputs --ignore-metadata --ignore-details
```

Basically I'd like to be able to diff the notebook as if it was converted to a plain text file, only keeping track of input-cells type and content.

items.title: nbmerge-web throws "Invalid cell decision" and "c is undefined"
items.body:
I am trying to do a simple notebook merge, and web tool for conflict resolution does not work as I want it to. I am not sure if it's a bug, or I am just using it wrong.
Version:
```bash
nbdime --version
0.4.1
```

I have a simple [git repo](https://github.com/antonbabkin/nbdime-demo).

Initial commit only has one markdown cell. Development further diverges into "alice" and "bob" branches, reflecting parallel development of independent features. Each branch adds a single markdown cell. After that, branches must be merged.

Merged notebook should have 3 markdown cells.
1. First cell from "master" (base).
2. Second cell from "alice".
3. Third cell from "bob".

Here is what I do:
```bash
nbdime config-git --enable
git checkout bob
git merge alice
# conflicts occured
nbdime mergetool
```
Web tool opens, I see first cell as unchanged, then bob's cell as local and then alice's cell as remote, in that order, no parallel cells. I want to simply reorder them, so I drag alice's cell above bob's. Then I press "Save" button, but nothing happens. In browser console this error appears:
```
Error: Invalid cell decision    exceptions.ts:15:4
NotifyUserError   exceptions.ts:15:4
CellMergeModel.prototype.serialize    cell.ts:333:14
NotebookMergeModel.prototype.serialize    notebook.ts:115:15
extractMergedNotebook    save.ts:23:11
saveMerged.   merge.ts:192:11
```

If I then press "Download", I get this error:
```
TypeError: c is undefined [Learn More]    notebook.ts:130:6
get    notebook.ts:130:6
get    notebook.ts:138:19
downloadMerged    merge.ts:245:6
```

Nothing happens with the notebook, and so the merge conflict is not resolved.

`nbdiff` and `nbdiff-web` work fine. Here's the diff of alice and bob.
```
nbdiff 33e7 0e66
nbdiff main.ipynb (33e7) main.ipynb (0e66)
--- main.ipynb (33e7)  (no timestamp)
```

items.title: Metadata comparison should be optional
items.body:
Metadata comparison should be optional just like hiding unchanged cells.
The following situation is common:
  * `ExecuteTime` Jupyter addon writes last execution time and date into metadata
  * Cells are being executed thus execution time and date updates
  * We get many 'changed' cells that are identical

items.title: frontend-extension not working with jupyter-hub
items.body:
The front-end plugin doesn't seem to work in jupyter-hub. 

Here is what I have tried: 

I made a single-user dockerfile. Executing it directly works like a charm. But when I execute it via jupyterhub, nbdime's nbextension breaks. I suspect this is due to the routing of jupyter hub. 
I believe the problem is, that dockerhub doesn't forward the URL  to the server-extension. I hope it is possible to configure jupyterhub in such a way, that the server-extension works. 

### reproduction 

Here is my minimal working setup: 

Dockerfile: 

```
FROM jupyter/minimal-notebook:e1677043235c
RUN python3 -m pip install jupyterhub==0.8.0 nbdime
USER root
RUN nbdime reg-extensions --system
USER jovyan
```

execute it with:

`docker build -t tc .;and docker run -it --name cc --rm -p 8888:8888 tc` 

result (after clicking button "checkpoint diff" in a new notebook): 

![bildschirmfoto vom 2017-12-12 16-12-21](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4362465/33892324-cf146612-df58-11e7-87d3-64d4c378f7bc.png)

as expected: just an empty diff. 

But when I execute the same Dockerfile via the dockerspawner in jupyter hub, I get this instead after clicking the same button: 

![bildschirmfoto vom 2017-12-12 16-11-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4362465/33892290-b97f1766-df58-11e7-8e82-0771c3840626.png)

As you can see, the URL is different here: "user/bjoern" was added before "/nbdime/"

___

My Dockerhub is based on [jupyterhub-deploy-docker](https://github.com/jupyterhub/jupyterhub-deploy-docker).

The changes I made to jupyterhub-deploy-docker: in the folder "singleuser" is the Dockerfile form above. My version uses dockerhub 0.8.0 (0.8.1 doesn't seem to build for me) and Docker 1.17.03, so I removed the args before "FROM" and replaced them literal values.  Also I use a dummy-authenticator instead of  github-auth. I don't think, that any of my changes are responsible for breaking nbdime. 
___

items.title: Diff does not show indentation changes
items.body:
I am using nbdime and I had the following problem with it today. I was editing this Python code:

```python
with open("numbers.txt") as f:
    l = []
    for line in f:
        l.append(float(line.strip()))
    l.sort()
    l.reverse()
```

To this code:

```python
with open("numbers.txt") as f:
    l = []
    for line in f:
        l.append(float(line.strip()))
l.sort()
l.reverse()
```

Ie I changed the indentation of the last two list. However, the diff looked like this:

```
## modified /cells/2/source:
@@ -13,5 +13,5 @@ with open("numbers.txt") as f:
    l = []
    for line in f:
        l.append(float(line.strip()))
l.sort()
l.reverse()
```

with no coloring at all, which made me think nothing had changed. I think indentation changes should be shown much more prominently, particularly for a Python tool!

items.title: give the option to ignore output cells
items.body:
In general output cells may more likely differ, for instance when you run the same notebook on different computers. This generates sometimes conflicts for which ``nbdiff`` is a great tool.

Adding the option to ignore the output and to concentrate on the content would be a great addition to the tool to focus on the most important part of the differences.
